artist: Masami Teraoka; Publisher: Space Gallery, Los Angeles
medium: Color woodcut with watercolor on Hosho paper
portfolio: From the series 31 Flavors Invading Japan
provenance: [Space Gallery, Los Angeles]; sold to MIA, 1981.
text: Masami Teraoka uses the conventions of 19th-century Japanese ukiyo-e woodblock prints to create absurdist parodies of consumerism, pollution and greed. It's a style he developed after moving to Los Angeles in 1961 at age 25, when Pop art was hitting its stride. A major theme is the way American tastes are imposed on other cultures. In noting Teraoka's undercurrent of lusty imagery, Asian art expert Howard A. Link refers to his snake-like tongues devouring ice cream cones. For his palette, Teraoka draws inspiration from his family's kimono shop.
title: 31 Flavors Invading Japan: Today’s Special
